keyTakeAways: US District Judge Sara Ellis issued a sweeping order to prevent federal agents from using tear gas, less-lethal munitions, and force against peaceful protesters, journalists, and clergy in Chicago.

The judge expanded the order to require all federal agents involved in Operation Midway Blitz to wear body cameras during encounters with protesters, citing concerns over violations of constitutional rights and lack of transparency.
Federal agents, particularly from ICE and DHS, have been accused of deploying tear gas and pepper balls without warnings, including toward reporters and a pastor during demonstrations.
The Department of Justice and DHS argued that body camera implementation would require excessive resources and could not be practically managed, but the court insisted on compliance.
Illinois Governor JB Pritzker supported the judge’s actions, stating that the reports of misconduct are truthful and that more legal actions are likely against ICE and CBP.
An appellate court denied the Trump administration’s request to deploy National Guard troops in Illinois, citing unreliable assessments of unrest, though troops can remain under federal control.
Tensions exist between immigration agents and FBI agents over body camera use, with some immigration agents refusing joint operations due to privacy and tactical concerns.
The judge expressed concern over media reports being selectively edited or one-sided, prompting her to demand explanations from ICE Field Director Russell Hott.

summaryOfNewsArticle: US District Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, expanded a temporary restraining order issued in response to allegations that federal agents, including ICE and US Border Patrol, used excessive force—such as tear gas and pepper balls—against peaceful protesters, journalists, and clergy during demonstrations in Chicago. The judge demanded explanations from ICE Field Director Russell Hott over reports of tear gas deployment without warning and mandated that all agents involved in Operation Midway Blitz wear body cameras during protests to ensure transparency. While the Department of Justice and DHS argued that implementing body cameras would be logistically and resource-intensive, the judge insisted on compliance. The case highlights growing tensions between federal enforcement agencies and civil liberties advocates, with Illinois Governor JB Pritzker supporting the judicial action. Additionally, a federal appellate court blocked the Trump administration’s attempt to deploy National Guard troops in Illinois, calling their threat assessments unreliable, signaling a broader judicial and public skepticism of federal overreach in urban protests.
title: Federal judge demands answers from Trump admin on following order to avoid violent encounters with Chicago protesters
